title.narrative: Kinda! Smallholder farmers in western Kenya achieving sustainable livelihoods

description.narrative:
Output 1.1: Targeted farmers' organizations use sound governance and management practices - Strengthen governance capacity of APOKO leadership - Put in place strategic plans for APOKO
Output 1.2. Targeted farmers' organizations provide quality services - Upgrade coffee factory infrastructure for Kabondo, Pala and Ayoro - Put in place Model Farmer structure
Output 1.3. APOKO mobilizes internal financial resources to provide financial service to member FCS and farmers - Operationalize the APOKO SACCO (saving and credit cooperative society) - Build capacity of APOKO and FCS to access financial services
Output 2.1. Targeted farmers plan and operate their farms that is responsive to the market - Promote banana and beans as alternative high value crops for income generation. - Build capacity of farmers to practice farming as a business
Output 2.2. Targeted farmers implement sound agriculture to respond to a variable climate - Provide hands-on experience for farmer learning - Conduct best farmer competition
Output 2.3. Targeted farmers expand their access to financial services - Create village level financial services for farmers

The project is designed to address the challenges threatening agricultural livelihoods of farmers in Rachuonyo South sub-county; Homabay County, Western Kenya. Agricultural livelihoods of smallholder coffee farmers in Rachuonyo South are vulnerable to market price volatility and effects of changing climate. The overall goal of the Kinda project is to empower smallholder coffee farmers in Rachuonyo South to become resilient to market price volatility and changing climate through sustainable agriculture while its strategic objective is to support the targeted smallholder coffee farmers to increase their incomes from marketing of high value crops. Outcome 1: Targeted farmers' organizations (APOKO and its member primary FCS) operate viable businesses Outcome 2: Targeted smallholder coffee farmers operate viable farm businesses
